Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ARTHUR R. DOHLEN
Present address: EARL GREY
Pioneer address: EARL GREY
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905
Country or place from which you came: MIRAMICHI, NEW BRUNSWICK

Note to Persons Answering the Pioneer Housing Questionnaire:

Since early settlers lived in very different kinds of houses from one time to another, and according to different circumstances, this questionnaire has been divided into three parts:

PART I: The "temporary" shack, sod or log house.
- To include any early dwellings coming under this general description, even though the family may have lived in it for many years.

PART II: The permanent house.
- To include the better house built after living for a time in quarters mentioned above, a permanent house built upon arrival, or the "homestead shack" which may have been added to and continued as a permanent house.

PART III: General aspects applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.
- Including aspects affecting your life in the past.

Some persons will therefore answer only part two and others will be able to answer all three parts.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER HOUSING

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ARTHUR R. DOHLEN
Present address: EARL GREY
Pioneer address: EARL GREY
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1903
Country or place from which you came: MICHIGAN

Note to Persons Answering the Pioneer Housing Questionnaire:

Since early settlers lived in very different kinds of houses from one time to another, and according to different circumstances, this questionnaire has been divided into three parts:

PART I: The "temporary" shack, sod or log house.
- To include any early dwellings costing under $500, generally described as "shanties," even though the family may have lived in it for many years.

PART II: The permanent house.
- To include the better house built after living for a time in quarters mentioned above, a permanent house built upon arrival, or the improved shanty which may have been added to and continued as a permanent house.

PART III: General aspects applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.
- Including aspects applying to either Part I or Part II of the questionnaire.

Some persons will therefore answer only Parts two and three, and others will be able to answer all three parts.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PART II: THE TEMPORARY SHACK, SOD OR LOG HOUSE.

1. What year was this house built? 1925

2. During what years did you live in it? 1925-1938

How long did you think you might live in it when you built it? 10 years

3. What was the location (township, range, and point office)? SW¼ - 33 - 20 NW¼ SW¼ - 33 - 20 NE¼ SW¼ - 33 - 20

4. Is it still in existence? Yes

5. What material was it made of? Sod, brick, and lathes

6. How long did it take to build it? Perhaps 6 months

7. Who built it? Earl Grey

8. How large was it, and how many rooms did it contain? 18' x 24', 6 rooms

9. How were they arranged? On one floor

10. What expenses did you have connected with the building of the house? Number for living and floors

11. Describe any special problems or unusual happenings connected with its building. Plowing and cutting sod

12. How many people lived in the house when it was first built? 6

13. What means of heating did you have? Wood stove

14. What means of lighting did you use? Kerosene lamps

15. Was there a cellar? No

Where was the door to the cellar? In kitchen floor, other place?

PART II: THE PERMANENT HOME

15. Give the location (township, range, and post office) of the house, (or houses) described in this part of the questionnaire, and the years you lived in it (or them). If you lived in other houses besides those you intend to describe in this questionnaire, give their location, and the years you lived in each.

16. Who planned and built the house?

17. Where did he get his ideas as to the kind of house to build?

18. What year was it built? 1908

19. How long did it take to build it? (If possible, give approximate dates when started and completed.)

20. Does it still exist? Yes

21. What material was it made of? Stone

22. How large was it? 24 x 24

23. Describe the arrangement of the rooms or, preferably, draw a floor plan of the house. (On a separate sheet, if desired.)

24. Was there a back shed attached? Built in 1927

25. Did you have a iron porch? No

26. Was a crawl space under the house (wooden stilts, stone, concrete)?

27. What kind of a basement did you have? (All size cement basement, dirt cellar, etc.)
PART II: THE PERMANENT HOME

Note: For some persons, this section may include a description of more than one house. If so, you may have to answer for each dwelling separately. You may choose from one house or another if you wish.

16. Give the location (township, county, and post office), of the house, (or houses) described in this part of the questionnaire, and the years you lived in it (or them). If you lived in other houses besides those you intend to describe in this questionnaire, give their location and the years you lived in each.

17. Who planned and built the house?

What previous experience did this person (or persons) have in building? No experience.

Where did he get his ideas as to the kind of house to build?

18. What year was it built? 1908

19. How long did it take to build it? (If possible, give approximate dates when started and completed)? Yes, Summer of 1908

20. Does it still exist? Yes

21. What material was it made of? Stone

22. How large was it? 24 X 24

23. Describe the arrangement of the rooms or, preferably, draw a floor plan of the house. (On a separate sheet, if desired).

Was there a back shed attached? No

Did you have a front porch? No

Was there a basement? Yes

What kind of foundation was under the house (wooden stilts, stone, concrete)?

What kind of a basement did you have (all stone, cement, dirt cellar, etc.)?

Where was the door to the basement? (Kitchen, outside, other room?)
Dohlin home
built in 1908
Dohlen home
built in 1908
26. What insulation was used? Double stone walls

27. Describe the general exterior appearance of the house (square, rectangular, T or L shaped, sharply sloped roof, etc.)
   Picture enclosed

Describe any ornamentation on the exterior of the house (for example, "gingerbread" trim, carved cornices etc.)

What color was the house, and what color trim was used?

28. How were interior walls finished - (plaster, wood panel, wallpaper etc.)?
   Bedrooms plaster - other rooms wall paper

29. How high were the ceilings? 8 1/2 ft.

How were they finished (plaster, beamed, moulded plaster)? V-joint

30. What kind of wood were the floors made of? Flooring

What width board?

Were nails or dowels used? Nails

Did you have any parquet (patterned inlay) flooring? No

31. Describe the windows as nearly as you can, giving size (length and width), size of panes, height from floor and distance from ceiling.

How were the windows arranged? See picture

Did you have a bay window? No In what room?

Did you have any colored or stained glass windows? No Describe.

Did you have shutters inside or outside? No

How were window frames finished inside (painted, varnished)?
outside (painted to contrast with house color)?

32. Describe your front door (panelled door, windows in door, or around or above). Common door

What kind of hardware was used on the door - (iron, brass etc.)?

Did you have a door knocker? No Describe.

33. Describe interior doors, - if panelled, type of hardware, or any other special features about them. Ordinary doors

Did you have any double doors, french doors or swinging doors? No

What material were door handles made of - brass, iron, porcelain (white or colored), glass?

34. If you had an upstairs, was the stairway open or closed? Open

If open, what type of baluster and rail was used, and what kind of wood?

35. Did you have any built in cupboards, bookcases, china storage or other similar built in storage or display space? No

36. What kind of a chimney did you have? Brick

37. If you had a fireplace, where was it located in the house?
What material was it made of - red brick (what size brick?), stone (state color) or other material?
How large was the fireplace?
What material was the mantle made of (wood, stone, brick)?

38. Were there any built in gas lights or lamp brackets; or candle brackets?
Was electrical wiring included? No

39. Describe the means of lighting provided when you first lived in the house, and changes made in later years, giving dates if possible when changes occurred?
Candle, oil lamps - gasoline lamps around year 1925
House was wired for electricity in 1955

40. Describe heating arrangements, in early years and later, giving dates of changes if possible.
Wood burning cook stove
Wood coal burning furnace installed 1918
Oil burning furnace installed 1960

41. Did you have a cistern? No
What size and material?
Was the pump from it in the kitchen, basement or elsewhere?
Did you have a well in the basement? No
Outside near the House?

If so, what was the source of water?

The source?
No loan
What was the interest rate?

What material was the mantle made of (wood, stone, brick)? Were there any built-in gas lighting or lamp brackets or candle brackets?

38. Was electrical wiring included?

39. Describe the means of lighting provided when you first lived in the house, and changes made in later years, giving dates if possible when changes occurred.

40. Describe heating arrangements, in early years and later, giving dates of changes if possible. Wood burning cook stove, oil, electric, hot water, central heating, furnace installed 1918, oil burning furnace installed 1918, oil burning furnace installed 1955.

PART III: GENERAL.

Note: As you may have more than one answer for questions in this section, as they apply to houses mentioned in either Part 1 or Part 2, please specify which house you are speaking of if more answers does not apply to both cases. Use extra sheets if necessary.

46. What did you do to "winterize" your house in the fall (stoves, windows, doors, banking (with what), other names)?

47. What additions were built to the house after its original construction?

Part 2 — Back kitchen built in 1927

For what reasons? Odd work area.

48. What animals were in the house at any time? (e.g., dogs, cats or other pets, baby chicks, sick animals or others).

49. As nearly as you can remember tell what furniture you had in each room in the house, (rugs, sofas, chairs, curtains, musical instruments, etc., etc.). If you lived at first in the "shack" or sod house, and later in a larger house, please tell what furniture you had in each place.

No rec. — It was all brought from Winn.

50. How much of this furniture did you bring with you when you came and where was it made or purchased?

How much of it do you still have today? None.

Describe any items of furniture which were outstanding, or would seem strange in the modern home.

How did you get furniture during the first few years? (make it, from Eaton's etc.)

Bought it from Winn.

51. Do you have any pictures of early pieces of furniture, or interior views of your house, which you would be willing to loan or present to the Archives?

If requested to do so, would you be willing to co-operate in having pictures taken of any unusual or rare piece of furniture which you might possess?

Yes but I don't possess any.
Part 1 - Back Kitchen built in 1927

No, we... It was all bought from Winn.

How much of it do you still have today? None.

Describe any items of furniture which were outstanding or would be stored in the modern house.

You did you get furniture during the first few years? (make it)

Do you have any pictures of early pieces of furniture, or interior views of your house, which you would be willing to loan or present to the Archives?

If requested to do so, would you be willing to cooperate in having pictures taken of any unusual or rare pieces of furniture which you might possess?

You had 5 item 6 purchased by
51. Did you or any of your neighbors have looms for weaving, or spinning wheels? No

52. Tell what furnishings were made for the home, for example, rugs, window curtains, table covers, items of furniture etc.

My mother & sisters made all the curtains.

53. When did you get your first radio? 1925
What kind was it? No rec.
Where did you get it? From mail order cat.

54. What use was made of the attic (as a sleeping room? for storage space? for ripening, drying, or storing vegetables?) No attic

What windows or means of ventilation were provided in the attic?

55. Did you have an indoor toilet? No

56. Did you have any kind of a windbreak (trees, or a windbreak built to protect the house or the door, and from what direction)?
Natural poplar & wild berry bluff on west side.

57. Tell what measures were taken for fire protection, mentioning changes in the form of protection throughout the years, giving dates if possible. (for example, fireguards, lightning rods, fire insurance).
The farm buildings have always been insured.

58. Describe any memorable incidents or features connected with any home in which you have lived, not already mentioned in your answers.
There was a slight earthquake in the summer of 1908 which cracked the east wall of the stone well. This crack is still there.

57. Tell what measures were taken for fire protection, mentioning changes in the form of protection throughout the years, giving dates if possible. (For example, firegrants, lightning rods, fire insurance).

The farm buildings have always been covered.

58. Describe any memorable incidents or features connected with any house in which you have lived, not already mentioned in your answers.

There was a slight earthquake in the summer of 1909 which cracked the east wall of the stone well. This crack is still there.
